title: In English, do you say 'a holy' or 'an holy'? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends. In the UK, officially, all ‘h’ words are treated as if they start with a vowel - an hotel, an historic moment, an holy night. That’s because ‘h’ isn’t exactly a consonant, it’s more of an additional breath before the vowel. If you listen to people speaking ‘RP’ or ‘BBC English’, which is basically the standard UK upper-middle-class speech that you’ll hear up and down the country with only a relatively minor variation in regional accent, they’ll usually speak it that way, especially if they’re being careful to speak ‘properly’. But almost no one else will do it. Some regional accents drop the ‘h’ altogether, making it more like ‘an ‘oly night’, often elided into ‘a noly night’. And when people do voice the h, they’ll usually treat it as a consonant: ‘a holy night’. Generally, using ‘an holy’ will make you sound rather self-conscious unless you are in very formal circumstances. Alan Bennett wrote a famous comedy monologue mocking pompous religious sermons that starts by quoting the Bible verse: “My brother Esau is an hairy man, but I am a smooth man”

A simple rule describes how to deal with words beginning with the letter ‘h’. If the ‘h’ is aspirant (that is you can hear it, as with ‘hotel’ or ‘history’) then it is preceded by ‘a’. If the ‘h’ is silent and you hear only the vowel that follows it (honour, honest, hour) then it takes ‘an’. ‘Holy’ has an aspirant ‘h’. Some dialects, particularly those in London, don’t aspirate words when they should. This is called ‘dropping your ‘h’s’. Other people do the reverse.
